section.title: Computing changes
section.para: Initial values in the model can be changed using mathematical rules, using model variables or user defined parameters:

listitem.para: In the workflow.xml file, replace the third changeAttribute node (the one setting the value of k3) by the following code:
listitem.programlisting: <computeChange target="/sbml:sbml/sbml:model[@id='FEBS']/sbml:listOfParameters/sbml:parameter[@id='k3']/@value"> <listOfVariables> <variable id="k1" name="k1" modelReference="febs_model" target="/sbml:sbml/sbml:model[@id='FEBS']/sbml:listOfParameters/sbml:parameter[@id='k1']/@value" /> <variable id="k2" name="k2" modelReference="febs_model" target="/sbml:sbml/sbml:model[@id='FEBS']/sbml:listOfParameters/sbml:parameter[@id='k2']/@value" /> </listOfVariables> <listOfParameters> <parameter id="k" name="denominator" value="2.0" /> </listOfParameters> <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <apply> <divide /> <apply> <plus /> <ci>k1</ci> <ci>k2</ci> </apply> <ci>k</ci> </apply> </math> </computeChange>
listitem.para: This computeChange node computes a new value for the target k3 using two model variables (parameters k1 and k2) and a pre-defined parameter k which value is 2.0. As the order of the changes matters, and the changeAttribute elements for k1 and k2 were kept, their new values are used.
Variables used in the computation are not limited to variables from the target model: variables from other models can be used too.
